IRM 3.30.10, Cost Estimate Reference, dated February 20, 2017, is superseded.
AUDIENCE

A wide variety of areas use IRM 3.30.10 Cost Estimate Reference, primarily used in Submission Processing within W&I and SB/SE and CAS in TEGE. Some of these areas include: the Submission Processing HQ program analysts, TIGTA, GAO, Contractors working for IRS on Reorganization issues, Congress, Treasury and OMB.
Director, Submission Processing Customer Account Services Wage and Investment Division

A Cost Estimate can be used to Examples Estimate costs or • New programs savings • New or proposed legislation • Request for programming support via a Work Request Management System (WRMS) • Procedural or processing changes • Workload shift between programs or functions Evaluate processes • Employee suggestions • Procedure/System Change Requests Support resource • Budget submissions planning • Work Plan/Work Schedule process • Reimbursable projects • User funded programs Provide manage- • Special requests ment information • Management discretion
This IRM and associated Document
provides historical processing data for our organization, so it should be used as a primary reference tool when preparing a cost estimate.

Caution: Preparation of a cost estimate DOES NOT mean funding is available, but a cost estimate is often required to support a request for funding. Also, if the WRTS, employee suggestion, or new program is approved, the cost estimate may become the basis for +/- staffing adjustment at the Submis- sion Processing campus(es).
) This section explains how to use the statistical data referenced in this IRM associated Document
exhibits to prepare a cost estimate. Steps (
) Before you begin to prepare a cost estimate, you must become familiar the process you are costing. (
) To prepare a cost estimate, take the following steps:
Determine if the cost estimate is for an existing or new function or program.
Prepare assumptions for your cost estimate.
Determine workﬂow process; prepare a ﬂow chart of the process.
Compute speciﬁc processing costs.
Compute actual processing costs.
Prepare summary.
Determine and add Non-Labor costs, if applicable. (

) When you prepare a cost estimate for an existing function or program a deﬁned work ﬂow should already exist. Review the work ﬂow to determine something will be: • Added • Deleted • Or worked in a different area. If so, be sure to include the impact on other areas. Note: A recent legislative change will send additional Form
, U.S.
Note: A recent legislative change will send additional Form
, U.S. Individual Income Tax Returns, to the Error Resolution System (ERS) for review. Existing OFP code data can be used to determine the resource impact to process these additional returns. (

) When you prepare a cost estimate for a new function or program, you should: • Develop assumptions • Determine similarities to another function or program • Determine if it is covered by an interagency reimbursable agreement. If so, include all costs to ensure the Service is fully reimbursed for all resources expended.
Develop assumptions
Determine similarities to another function or program
Determine if it is covered by an interagency reimbursable agreement. If so, include all costs to ensure the Service is fully reimbursed for all

An assumption may pertain to: Example Volume This change will increase BMF Unpostable receipts by 50,000 cases annually, nationwide. Production rates The production rate for process- ing these additional cases is the same as the current BMF Un- postable rate. Areas of impact There will be no impact on the Files area. Employees do not need source documents to resolve these cases. Comparisons This form will be processed similarly to current Form 720, Quarterly Federal Excise Tax Return. Exclusions Only labor costs are included. Equipment costs are not included.

As deﬁned above, a ﬂow chart is typically a diagram. In lieu of a diagram, you can also identify the work ﬂow in an SP campus by listing each task or activity that will be performed in the process and the corresponding OFP code.
The following table shows an example of a work ﬂow process for an existing process. See Document 6746, Exhibit 19 for Receipt and Control Flowchart.

) The direct labor costs are the hours and costs it takes to perform the work. The direct labor cost does not include management and supervision, overhead, or beneﬁts, but it does include overtime, night differential and locality pay . (
) Although Quality Assurance is generally considered a direct labor cost, it is computed until after the non-Quality Assurance hours and costs are (
) SP campus labor costs for existing programs should always have an OFP code associated with it. (
) You may use Document
, Exhibits
and
to compute direct labor for existing OFP codes included in the SP campus work ﬂow diagram or chart. (
) First, look at Document
, Exhibit
to locate the function/program you need. Remember these are arranged by organization. (
) An asterisk appears to the left of a function/program in Document
when production/hours are reported by more than one organization. (
) If an asterisk appears for the entries, see Document
, Exhibit
which provides a list of all the organizations reporting that function and program. (
) It is important to determine what data to use for your cost estimate. on the scope of the cost estimate, you may use data from all or only some the organizations listed (
) To calculate the labor cost follow the steps below:
Make an assumption to identify the anticipated volume (production) Labor your cost estimate.
Locate the OFP code in Document
, Exhibit
or
to obtain the adjusted rate and cost per staff hour.
Divide the volume by the adjusted rate to obtain staff hours.
Multiply the staff hours (obtained in step
above) by the cost per hour for that OFP to obtain the direct labor cost
Repeat steps
until the cost for all OFP codes have been
Add the staff hours for each OFP to obtain the staff hours for the process.
Add the cost for each OFP code to obtain the labor cost for the

) Quality Assurance (QA) is that portion of time and related costs that are to review the work performed in the SP campus(es). (
) Although QA is considered a direct cost, it is calculated as a percentage of direct labor costs to do the actual work. (
) This percentage is the total of the authorized percentages for Quality as computed in the Work Plans. (
) The cost per staff hour for all Function
(Quality Assurance) hours combined is then used to calculate the labor cost. (
) The staff hours and costs for QA changes are calculated based on the FY
QA ﬁgures in Document
, Exhibit
Table (B). (
) The staff hours and costs for QA are added to Direct Labor staff hours and cost before Overhead is calculated. (
) Follow the steps below to obtain Quality Assurance hours and costs:
Multiply the direct hours in your cost estimate by the QA percentage (Document
, Exhibit
Table (B)) to obtain the number of
required.
Multiply the QA hours (from step
above) by the QA cost per hour (Document
, Exhibit
Table (B)) to get the cost to perform the function.
Add the QA hours to the direct hours.
Add the QA cost to the direct cost. (

data is below. This example is a continuation of the example used in IRM

, Exhibit
Table (B)) to obtain the number of
hours required.

above) by the QA cost per hour (Document
, Exhibit
Table (B)) to get the cost to perform the QA function.
Add the QA hours to the direct hours.
Add the QA cost to the direct cost.

Overhead hours are those staff hours used for administrative functions, and training. Overhead costs are reported as Function

There are several different Overhead percentages to choose from when preparing a cost estimate. The most important thing to remember is to select the Overhead that best ﬁts what is represented in your cost estimate. There are different Overhead percentages for Wage and Investment (W&I) and Small and Self Employed (SBSE). Refer to Document
, Exhibit

Table (A) speciﬁc details. Management and Supervision costs are generally not included in the percentage for most cost estimates we prepare. Management and Supervision costs are usually only included in cost for: • New programs • Legislative changes • Reimbursable programs • Signiﬁcant increases or decreases in hours Management and Supervision hours are reported by the Submission ing campus(es) in Function
Program
XX.
Management and Supervision includes Work Leader/Senior hours, 5911X.

) When your cost estimate pertains to a new process, you may want to overhead hours in your cost estimate for additional training or and supervision. Any additional needs should be fully documented and identiﬁed as early possible, so they can be considered in the Submission Processing (SP) Campus Work Plan process. The government contribution toward the cost of the items listed below are Beneﬁts: • Social Security (both FICA and Medicare) • Federal Employees Group Life Insurance (FEGLI) • Federal Employee Health Beneﬁt (FEHB) • Federal Employees Retirement System (FERS) • Civil Service Retirement System (CSRS) • Thrift Savings Plan (TSP) Use Exhibit
Table (A) for Beneﬁts percentage for the appropriate tion. The Submission Processing WI Beneﬁts percentage for FY

is percent. Compute Beneﬁts on staff costs only. Since Beneﬁts represent a monetary contribution, there is no related hour computation. Beneﬁts are computed after all of the following costs have been • Direct cost (excluding QA) • Quality Assurance • Overhead To compute the Beneﬁts cost, take the following steps:
Use Document
, Exhibit
Table (A) and ﬁnd the appropriate Beneﬁts percentage (we will use Submission Processing WI).
Multiply the Subtotal Labor cost by
percent .

Non-labor costs are expenses incurred for things other than salaries paid to perform the work. Examples of non-labor expenses are: • Postage, Printing and Shipping • Supplies • Federal Record Center Charges • Basic support Non-labor costs are generally not a mandatory item in a cost estimate. They may be included when they are a signiﬁcant part of the cost. It is important to keep labor and non-labor costs separate so staffing adjust- ments are not made based upon non-labor costs. See Document
, Exhibits
through
for additional information on non-labor costs. If you need additional assistance, contact the Resource Section, SE:W:CAS:SP:PM:R.

(06-25-2018) Guidelines for Fall-Out Percentages Exhibits
) Document
, Exhibits
through
show the fallout percentages for the major processing functions. (
) Using Document
FY
data, we have computed fall-out percentages which may be used to estimate future workload in functional areas in the SP campuses. (

) Fall-out percentages are determined in different ways depending on the workﬂow and the functions. Column headings and exhibit footnotes provide additional information on how the fall-out percentages were calculated. (
) In some instances, it is more appropriate to deviate from the published percentages.
Example: When anticipated increase in error resolution items due to validity checks.
) Follow the steps below to compute estimated volumes based on fall-out per- centages:
Select the appropriate Exhibit for your OFP from Document
through
to determine the fallout percentage.
Multiply the volume by the fall-out percentage to determine the fall-out volume. (

) Support ratios are calculated when the support activity does not report production rate or volume. Support activities are generally clerical functions necessary to prepare work for resolution by tax examiners or other technical employees, or to release the work to the next function. (
) Support activity relationships have been made so that clerical and other functions can be identiﬁed and included in cost estimates. (
) Due to various time reporting methods, it is sometimes difficult to capture the related support activity expenses.
) Document
Exhibits
through
provide percentages (ratios) that be used to allocate support activity hours. (
) The support ratios were obtained by making a relationship between the of work handled in a function and the number of support hours necessary support that function. (

) Although this is not an exact science, this method provides a way to make estimates for the future based on past experience. It includes the implicit sumption that the general relationship of support hours to volume will approximately the same. (
) The knowledge of exact volume or pre-determined staff hours eliminates need to make estimates using the support ratios. (
) Follow the steps below to calculate Support activity staff hours and costs:
Identify the volume that the support activity will be applied to.
Select the appropriate support ratio from Document
Exhibits

) by the support ratio (step
) to determine support activity hours.

The Cost per Thousand exhibits show the cost of processing 1,000 of the most common types of originally ﬁled tax returns or documents in the SP campuses.
Use the following example to see how to use fall-out percentages. Use Document 6746 Exhibit 7 Table (A) for Program 1110X Form 940, Annual Federal Unemployment (FUTA) Tax Return, for this example.

The ﬁrst part of Document

Cost per Thousand Exhibit provides the Pipeline Processing Costs for a return or document. To obtain each of the listed costs, logical divisions of processing steps were made, and their times and cost totaled.
When applicable, a cross reference to the related Document 6746 Functional Cost per Thousand exhibit is shown by the processing step.
3.30 Work Planning and Control

(3) A Pipeline Processing subtotal is provided and summary costs are computed on that amount. In many instances, it is appropriate to limit the cost estimate to those steps. At other times, it may be necessary to include some or all of the additional steps in the Speciﬁc Non-Pipeline Costs components, which are also provided. ) Four major processing components have been included in the Document
Speciﬁc Non-Pipeline Costs portion of the Cost per Thousand. These steps take place after initial processing of the return. (

) Depending upon the purpose of the cost estimate, you may decide to include some or all of these steps. In each instance, you must consider the purpose of the cost estimate to determine what must be included. (

) Subtotal the Speciﬁc Non-Pipeline costs or you may subtotal all processing steps and re-compute the three additional components to determine Total Labor. Either way may be appropriate, but be sure to clearly identify what your ﬁgures represent.
(06-25-2018) Speciﬁc Non-Pipeline Costs
Each of the two components of the Document
Cost per Thousand (Pipeline Processing Costs and Speciﬁc Non-Pipeline Costs) includes summary data which includes add-on costs for Quality Assurance, Overhead, and Beneﬁts.
page (

) For display purposes, each of the two components of the Cost per includes a subtotal and related summary information. In some instances, may prefer to subtotal steps from more than one component and compute summary information on the composite. Discretion should be used to determine when it is best to combine or keep components separate (e.g., when resource impact must be identiﬁed by funding activity.) In either case, you can use the Summary format from Document

3.30.10.10 (06-25-2018) Costing Estimated Volumes
There are two methods you can use to determine the cost to process your estimated volume using a Document 6746 Cost per Thousand exhibit.
Method 1 – Once you have determined your estimated volume, follow the steps below to compute the cost for processing that volume.

Step Action Result 1 Divide estimated volume The number of units of by 1,000 1,000 being processed 2 Multiply result from step 1 Total Labor Hours to (units of 1,000) by the process your volume. Total Labor Hours per Thousand from the appli- cable Table in Document 6746 Exhibit 33, 34, 35. 3 Multiply result from step 1 Total Labor Cost (dollars) (units of 1,000) by the to process your volume. Total Cost per Thousand from the applicable table in Document 6746 Exhibits 33, 34, 35.
Method 2 – You may prefer to compute the costs for your volume using Method 2 as explained below.

Step Action Result 1 Divide the Labor hours per The number of Labor thousand (found in hours to process one Document 6746 Exhibits document 33, 34, 35) by 1,000 2 Multiply your estimated The number of Labor volume by the result from hours to process your step 1 estimated volume 3 Divide the Total Labor cost The cost to process one per thousand (found in document Document 6746 Exhibits 33, 34, 35) by 1,000 4 Multiply your estimated The cost to process your volume by the result from volume step 3

When using the Document 6746 Cost per Thousand exhibits it is important to know what it is you need and to clearly identify the ﬁgures you provide to others. Pay close attention to the components of the Cost per Thousand and be sure you understand what your numbers
